claim: The maximum power conversion efficiency for single-junction perovskite solar cells is approximately 31% under standard test conditions.
rationale: Theoretical calculations based on the Shockley-Queisser limit and recent experimental advances indicate that perovskite materials can approach efficiencies near 31%. Record devices have achieved over 25% in laboratory settings.
caveats: Long-term stability and scalability remain challenges. The theoretical limit assumes ideal conditions not always met in practice.
next_experiment: Develop tandem architectures and improve material stability to push practical efficiencies closer to the theoretical maximum.
